title: Lincolnville Cemetery Entrance
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Photo of the steps leading up to the Lincolnville Cemetery in the parking lot of Carter-Finley Stadium.
locationincemetery: Fenced in area in the parking lot of Carter-Finley Stadim near Gate 6.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Lincolnville Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Unmarked and somewhat overgrown.
notes: There are 30 individuals buried here and the identity of one resident is known, Reverend John W. Dalton who died in 1943. The year 1875 was chosen because that was the time many of the Freedmen's Villages in Raleigh were founded. The Lincolnville site was displaced several times as North Carolina State University expanded so this project includes a cemetery census from Find A Grave that lists 87 individuals for Lincolnville Cemetery. It is difficult to verify the actual burial sites of many of these individuals as there is not currently access to the cemetery but as access to the site is granted, this information will be updated. For now this census is included with the hope of affording as many avenues of research as possible. Link to Lincolnville Cemetery records on Find A Grave

title: Lincolnville Cemetery #2 headstone
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Large standing granite, engraved headstone for the residents of Lincolnville Cemetery #2.
resident: Twelve unknown residents of Lincolnville Cemetery #2 formerly located near Gate 6 of Carter-Finley Stadium. At least one resident has been identified as Emerline White who died on April 7, 1922 and was a resident of the Lincolnville Community.
locationincemetery: Relocated Section on Hickory Avenue between Section A and Section E.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Lincolnville Cemetery; Oakwood Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Excellent condition.
epitaph: NCSU CEMETERY NO. 2/  THE ORIGINAL CEMETERY WAS LOCATED/  EAST OF THE WENDELL H. MURPHY/  FOOTBALL CENTER/  THIS PLOT CONTAINS THE REINTERED REMAINS/  OF TWELVE (12) UNKNOWN INDIVIDUALS/  THE CEMETERY WAS RELOCATED AUGUST 2015
notes: The remains of these 12 individuals were reinterred from their former resting place next to Gate 6 at Carter-Finley Stadium to Oakwood Cemetery in 2015. The indentities of these individuals is unknown except for that of Emerline White who died on April 7, 1922. The rest of the Lincolnville Cemetery was relocated to a fenced in wooded area of the Carter-Finley Stadium parking lot. The Lincolnville site was displaced several times as North Carolina State University expanded so this project includes a cemetery census from Find A Grave that lists 87 individuals for Lincolnville Cemetery. It is difficult to verify the actual burial sites of many of these individuals as there is not currently access to the site but as access to the site is granted, this information will be updated. For now this census is included with the hope of affording as many avenues of research as possible. Link to Lincolnville Cemetery records on Find A Grave

title: City Cemetery gate
creator: Suess, Kim
description: The main gate of City Cemetery in Raleigh, North Carolina at 17 South East Street. Wrought iron fence with solid black brick gate frame. Each side of the gate frame has metal two metal plaques.
locationincemetery: Main entrance/gate at 17 South East Street Raleigh, North Carolina
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; City Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Excellent condition
notes: City Cemetery was founded in 1798 and was the final resting place for Raleigh's citizens, including its enslaved population, until 1872 when Oakwood Cemetery and Mount Hope Cemetery were opened.
subject: City Cemetery; Raleigh; African-American Cemetery
rightsstatement: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 Deed | Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 4.0 International | Creative Commons

title: Monuments overlooking the African-American section of City Cemetery
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Three stone and monuments in front of an oak tree overlooking a mostly empty field. There are a few graves here and there.
locationincemetery: Sections B1-B4 and C1. The back right quadrant from the main entrance.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; City Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Excellent condition
notes: 1798 is the year City Cemetery was founded. It was used until 1872 for the burial of enslaved individuals and persons of color. According to the Raleigh City Cemeteries Preservation Inc. no burial post-dates 1872. There are some 1000 individuals buried in the one acre African-American section and there are records for 58 of these individuals from a 1979 cemetery census done by Betsy Shaw of the Raleigh City Cemeteries Preservation Inc. There are 87 grave markers for the estimated 1000 individuals laid to rest in this one acre area.
subject: City Cemetery; Raleigh; African-American Cemetery
rightsstatement: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 Deed | Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 4.0 International | Creative Commons

title: Monument dedicated to Cato
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Granite monument with a black metal plaque and gold lettering featuring the obituary of Cato, servant of the Boylan family.
locationincemetery: Sections B1-B4 and C1. The back right quadrant from the main entrance.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; City Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Excellent condition
epitaph: In memory of Cato, who is interred in this section of the/ cemetery in an unknown location.    Died On the 3d inst. of the consumption, after a confinement of 14/ months, Cato, a man of color, the property of Mr. William Boylan,/ of this city, but better known as the favorite slave of the late Mr./ [Abraham] Hodge of Halifax. Cato was a good printer and a/ tolerable book binder, and possessed a considerable share of wit and/ good understanding. He was decently interred in the burial ground/ of this city on Sunday evening last./ Raleigh Minerva, Feb. 7, 1881/ Donated by the Richard Godwin Family and/ Raleigh City Cemeteries Preservation, Inc./ June 2019
notes: It was most unusual at the time for an enslaved individual to have an obituary. Cato's owners, the Boylan family, owned the Raleigh Minerva that published his obituary.
subject: City Cemetery; Raleigh; African-American Cemetery; Cato
rightsstatement: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 Deed | Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 4.0 International | Creative Commons

title: Headstones of Anna Julia Cooper and husband George A.C. Cooper
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Large stone obelisk memorial for George A.C. Cooper next to smaller granite memorial for Anna Julia Cooper. The smaller memorial has a black metal plaque with gold lettering.
resident: Cooper, Dr. Anna Julia and Cooper, George A.C.
locationincemetery: Section A
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; City Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Excellent condition and well attended.
epitaph: ANNA JULIA COOPER PH.D./ 1859-1964/  EDUCATOR, AUTHOR, POET AND SCHOOL ADMINISTRATOR/  EARLY ADVOCATE OF EQUAL RIGHTS/  FOR BLACKS AND WOMEN/  A GRADUATE OF ST. AUGUSTINE'S COLLEGE/  ERECTED 1979
notes: Dr. Anna Julia Cooper is laid to rest next to her husband in section A which is across the path from the African-American section. George A.C. Cooper died in 1879 after they were married only two years. She never remarried and went on to become one of four Black women to recieve a PhD. Dr. Cooper's monument was erected in 1979, fifteen years after her death.
subject: City Cemetery; Raleigh; African-American Cemetery
rightsstatement: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 Deed | Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 4.0 International | Creative Commons

title: Anna Julia Cooper headstone
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Short granite headstone of Anna Julia Cooper with a black plaque with gold lettering on the front. There are sprigs of holly on the ground in front of the headstone.
locationincemetery: Section A
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; City Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Excellent condition and well attended.
epitaph: ANNA JULIA COOPER PH.D./ 1859-1964/  EDUCATOR, AUTHOR, POET AND SCHOOL ADMINISTRATOR/  EARLY ADVOCATE OF EQUAL RIGHTS/  FOR BLACKS AND WOMEN/  A GRADUATE OF ST. AUGUSTINE'S COLLEGE/  ERECTED 1979
notes: Dr. Anna Julia Cooper was born into slavery in 1858 and after emancipation attended Saint Augustine Normal and Collegiate Institute, going on to Oberlin College in 1881 and then to Paris in 1925 to earn her doctoral degree from the esteemed Sorbonne at the University of Paris. Dr. Cooper is laid to rest next to her husband in section A of City Cemetery which is across the path from the African-American section. Dr. Cooper's monument was erected in 1979, fifteen years after her death.
subject: City Cemetery; Raleigh; African-American Cemetery; Cooper, Anna Julia
rightsstatement: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 Deed | Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 4.0 International | Creative Commons

creator: Suess, Kim
description: Numerous tombstones in Mount Hope Cemetery on top of a hill framed by trees.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Mount Hope Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Well maintained.
notes: Mount Hope Cemetery was founded in 1872 and is Raleigh's first African-American cemetery. There are over 7000 individuals buried here. It is maintained by the City of Raleigh and is on the National Register of Historic Places.

title: Clarence Lightner grave marker
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Large horizontal granite, engraved stone with a photo of Clarence Lightner in the center with a marble border.
locationincemetery: Section E
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Mount Hope Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Well maintained.
epitaph: CLARENCE E. LIGHTNER/ AUGUST 15, 1921 - JULY 8, 2002/ PRESIDENT LIGHTNER FUNERAL HOME 1959-2000/ "BABY" LIGHTNER RALEIGH'S FIRST/ AFRICAN-AMERICAN MAYOR 1973-1975/ "OUR LOVE FOR YOU WILL LIVE ETERNALLY"
notes: Clarence Lightner served on the Raleigh City Council beginning in 1967 and in 1973 was elected the first Black mayor of Raleigh, serving from 1973-1975. Some of his many achievements include advancing an afforable housing agenda, civil rights work, and the creation of Citizen Advisory Councils (CACs). In 2009 he was inducted into the Raleigh Hall of Fame.
subject: Mount Hope Cemetery; Raleigh; African-American Cemetery; Lightner, Clarence
rightsstatement: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 Deed | Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 4.0 International | Creative Commons

title: Calvin Lightner grave marker
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Horizontal, rectangular, grey engraved headstone of Calvin Lightner.
locationincemetery: Section E
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Mount Hope Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Good condition. Slight discoloration across the epitaph.
epitaph: CALVIN E. LIGHTNER/  MAR. 31, 1876/  MAY 21, 1960/  FOUNDER OF/  LIGHTNER FUNERAL HOME, 1911
notes: Calvin Lightner founded the Lightner Funeral Home in 1911 which served the Black community until recently. Calvin Lightner was the first licensed African-American mortician, offering dignified services he saw lacking in the Black community. In 1920, Calvin and his brother Rayford bought a farm on what is now Old Garner Road and used part of that land to establish Hillcrest Cemetery, the first Black cemetery owned by the Black community.
subject: Mount Hope Cemetery; Raleigh; African-American Cemetery; Lightner, Calvin
rightsstatement: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 Deed | Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 4.0 International | Creative Commons

title: Dr. Manassa T. Pope headstone
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Standing grey headstone with cutout design and raised lettering.
locationincemetery: Section B, southside of Chavis Avenue
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Mount Hope Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Good condition, slight discoloration.
epitaph: 1 LT./ MANASSA T. POPE/ ASST./ SURG./ 3 N.C. INF./ SP. AM. WAR
notes: Dr. Pope was a graduate of Leonard Medical School at Shaw University. He volunteered during the Spanish American War with the Negro US Army, Third Regiment, North Carolina Infantry. Dr. Pope ran for mayor of Raleigh in 1919 and was the only Black man in the South to run for mayor during the Jim Crow era.
subject: Mount Hope Cemetery; Raleigh; African-American Cemetery; Pope, Dr. Manassa T.

creator: Suess, Kim
description: Stone column with a black metal plaque with gold lettering and a plaque at the foot of the column designating the site as a historic landmark.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Hillcrest Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Good condition.
notes: Hillcrest Cemetery was founded in 1920 by Calvin and Rayford Lightner and was the first Black owned cemetery in Raleigh. The wife of Judge George Royster Greene, Ruby Greene, founded the Friends of Hillcrest Cemetery in 2016 to raise funds to restore this historic cemetery. Hillcrest Cemetery is a Raleigh Historic Landmark.

title: George and Ruby Greene headstone
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Large rectangular engraved standing headstone of George and Ruby Greene with red and white flowers on the top.
locationincemetery: On the right side of the main gravel road.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Hillcrest Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Excellent condition. The stone is sinking a little on the left side.
epitaph: GREENE/  GEORGE ROYSTER/  OCTOBER 5, 1930/  MARCH 17, 2013/  RUBY POWELL/  OCTOBER 24, 1933
notes: Judge George Royster Greene was the first Black man elected judge in Wake County and served on both District and Superior courts for 20 years. Before becomming a judge, he represented college students that were arrested at lunch counter sit-ins in the early 1960s and was a civil rights activist. Judge Greene was elected into the Raleigh Hall of Fame in 2011. Hillcrest Cemetery was founded in 1920 by Calvin and Rayford Lightner and was the first Black owned cemetery in Raleigh. The wife of Judge George Royster Greene, Ruby Greene, founded the Friends of Hillcrest Cemetery in 2016 to raise funds to restore this historic cemetery. Hillcrest Cemetery is a Raleigh Historic Landmark.
subject: Hillcrest Cemetery; Raleigh; African-American Cemetery; Greene, Judge George Royster
rightsstatement: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 Deed | Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 4.0 International | Creative Commons

title: Berry O'Kelly headstone
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Large standing, textured headstone with a stately base in a grassy area with a footstone approximately 5 feet away. Engraved area is recessed and there is a boxwood covering up the lettering. The footstone is stately and engraved.
locationincemetery: Near Method Road in a grassy area next to the St. James's A.M.E. Church in front of the Method Community Park.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Method Community
conditionofburialsite: Excellent condition. The engraving on the main headstone is mostly obscured by a boxwood that appears to be growing out of the base.
epitaph: BERRY O KELLY/ DIED/ MARCH 14, 1931
notes: One of the first settlers of the Method Community, a Freedmen's Village known as Mason Village at the time, Berry O'Kelly became a successful businessman, banker, and land owner. In 1914 he founded the Berry O'Kelly Training School, one of three schools for Black citizens in the state. Berry O' Kelly was also the first postmaster of the Method community. O'Kelly is buried in front of what remains of that campus. The buildings are now part of the Method Comminity Park, maintained by the City of Raleigh. The site is on the National Register of Historic Places.
subject: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Method Community; Freedmen's village; O'Kelly, Berry
rightsstatement: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 Deed | Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 4.0 International | Creative Commons

title: James E Shepard grave marker
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Horizontal, engraved, marble grave marker.
locationincemetery: Section A; Plot 188
location: Durham, North Carolina; Durham County; Beechwood Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Good condition, some fadng and discoloration from the elements.
epitaph: JAMES E. SHEPHARD/ A LIFE DEDICATED TO/ SERVICE/ DIED OCT. 6, 1947
notes: Dr. James E Shepard was born in Raleigh, North Carolina and graduated from Shaw University in 1894. Dr. Shepard and his family settled in the Hayti District of Durham where he worked as a pharmacist. In 1910 Dr. Shepard founded the National Religious Training School and Chautauqua which would become the North Carolina College for Negroes in 1925. This was the first state supported liberal arts college for Black students in the United States. In 1972 the General Assembly changed its name to North Carolina Central University and Dr. Shepard was its president until his death in 1947.
subject: Durham, North Carolina; Durham County; Hayti District; North Carolina Central University; Shepard, Dr. James E.
rightsstatement: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 Deed | Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 4.0 International | Creative Commons

creator: Suess, Kim

locationincemetery: Section A; Plot 188
location: Durham, North Carolina; Durham County; Beechwood Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Good condition, some fadng and discoloration from the elements.
epitaph: SHEPARD
notes: The exact date of this monument is unknown so the year of Dr. Shepard's death was used. This stone indicates the location of the burial plot of the Shepard family.
subject: Durham, North Carolina; Durham County; North Carolina Central University; Shepard, Dr. James E.

title: James Sumner Lee grave marker
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Horizontal, engraved granite and marble grave marker.
locationincemetery: Section A; Plot 165
location: Durham, North Carolina; Durham County; Beechwood Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Good condition with some discoloration from the elements.There is a chip missing from the lower right corner of the marker.
epitaph: JAMES SUMNER LEE, SR./ DECEMBER 7, 1903/ JUNE 11, 1963
notes: Dr. James Sumner Lee was the Chairman of the Biology Department at North Carolina Central University from 1938 until his death in 1963. The James S. Lee Biology Building was dedicated to Dr. Lee in 1956. Dr Lee was a respected researcher in the field of microbiology. Dr. Lee was married to Mollie Huston Lee who was the first Black librarian in Raleigh, North Carolina and founded the Richard B. Harrison Library in Raleigh.
subject: Durham, North Carolina; Durham County; North Carolina Central University; Lee, Dr. James Sumner
rightsstatement: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 Deed | Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 4.0 International | Creative Commons

title: Mollie Huston Lee Burial site
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Grassy field dappled with flowers and horizontal grave markers.
locationincemetery: Section X; Plot 198
location: Durham, North Carolina; Durham County; Beechwood Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: The area is well maintained but the exact location of Mollie Lee's burial site is unmarked.
notes: After graduating from Howard University, Mollie Huston Lee went on to Columbia University's library school on a scholarship and in 1930 began working as a librarian at Shaw University. During her time at Shaw, Mollie Lee saw the need among the Black community in Raleigh to have their own library and collection of African-American literature. Since the only library in Raleigh at the time, the Olivia Raney Library, was only open to whites, Mollie Lee advocated with community members to Raleigh leaders for the establishment of the Richard B. Harrison Library, which opened in 1935. Over her 37 year career at the Richard B. Harrison Library, Mollie Lee collected over 5,000 volumes of Black literature ranging from adult and children's fiction, nonfiction, serials, pamphlets, and vertical file materials into what is known today as the "Mollie Huston Lee Collection of Black Literature." Mollie Lee was a pioneer in the library field, bringing library programming into rural Black communities and conducting outreach throughout Wake County to ensure all Black citizens had access to reading materials.
subject: Durham, North Carolina; Durham County; North Carolina Central University; Lee, Mollie Huston
rightsstatement: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 Deed | Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 4.0 International | Creative Commons

title: Oberlin Cemetery Raleigh Historic Landmark plaque and National Register of Historic Places plaque
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Two granite markers with bronze plaqes.
locationincemetery: Located on the ground just inside the main entrance of the cemetery.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Oberlin Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Well maintained with some discoloration due to the elements.
epitaph: 1: RALEIGH HISTORIC/ LANDMARK/ OBERLIN CEMETERY/ 1873-1971  2: OBERLIN CEMETERY/ ESTABLISHED 1873 BY AND FOR/ AFRICAN AMERICANS/ HAS BEEN PLACED ON THE/ NATIONAL REGISTER/ OF HISTORIC PLACES/ BY THE UNITED STATES/ DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR
notes: Founded in 1873, Oberlin Village Cemetery serves the community of Oberlin Village, one of thirteen Freedman's villages founded by newly emancipated Black individuals between 1865 and1870. Out of those thirteen Freedman's villages, the Oberlin and Method communities remain today. Oberlin Village is unique in that it began as an antebellum free Black enclave in 1858 when Jesse Pettiford, a free Black man, saved enough money to purchase a tract of land that would become Oberlin Village. Though there are only 139 markers, it is estimated that as many as 600 people are buried in the Oberlin Village cemetery. Today the Friends of Oberlin Village, which is a non-profit statted in 2012 by descendants of Oberlin Village's founders, maintains the cemetery and hosts tours, cleanup events, and fundraisers.
subject: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Oberlin Cemetery; Freedman's village; African-American Cemetery

title: Oberlin Cemetery
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Long shot of Oberlin Cemetery. Headstones dappled throughout a wooded area with a path through the middle.
locationincemetery: Right side of the cemetery from the entrance.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Oberlin Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Well maintained and clear walkways to the back of the cemetery. Lots of fall leaves and trees.
notes: Founded in 1873, Oberlin Village Cemetery serves the community of Oberlin Village, one of thirteen Freedman's villages founded by newly emancipated Black individuals between 1865 and1870. Out of those thirteen Freedman's villages, the Oberlin and Method communities remain today. Oberlin Village is unique in that it began as an antebellum free Black enclave in 1858 when Jesse Pettiford, a free Black man, saved enough money to purchase a tract of land that would become Oberlin Village. Though there are only 139 markers, it is estimated that as many as 600 people are buried in the Oberlin Village cemetery. Today the Friends of Oberlin Village, which is a non-profit statted in 2012 by descendants of Oberlin Village's founders, maintains the cemetery and hosts tours, cleanup events, and fundraisers.

title: Headstone of John T. Turner and his daughter Lula
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Large, stately, engraved granite headsone flanked by boxwoods with a basket of flowers in front of the base.
resident: Turner, John T. and daughter Lula
locationincemetery: Front part of the cemetery near the parking area in what is known as the Pine View annex, land donated by John T. Turner and annexed in 1924.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Oberlin Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Well maintained with some wear and discoloration due to the elements.
epitaph: JOHN T| DAUGHTER LULA/ TURNER/ DIED SEP 1922| DIED 1911/ AT REST
notes: John Thompson Turner was one of Oberlin Village's first settlers, going on to become a successful businessman and property owner in Raleigh. In 1889 John Turner purchased a home on Oberlin Road that he went on to transform into the Victorian inspired home that is still occupied by his descendants today. In 1924, John T. Turner annexed .57 acre of land to the Oberlin Cemetery known as the Pine View Cemetery. This section of Oberlin Cemetery is home to Turner's family plot. There are two symbols on the tombstone, above John Turner's name is the symbol of the Masonic order and above his daughter's name is the three link chain symbol of the Oddfellows order. The three links represent their motto "Friendship, Love, and Truth". The descendants of John T. Turner founded the non-profit Friends of Oberlin Village in 2012 which maintains the cemetery and hosts tours, cleanup, events, and fundraisers.

title: Long shot of Oak Grove Cemetery
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Various headstones in an area dappled with trees. There is highway construction going on in front of the cemetery.
locationincemetery: This is from the side of the cemetery accessed off of Ligon looking out toward the highway.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Oak Grove Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: There have been efforts to maintain the cemetery but highway construction has led to slumping of the ground and many of the plots closest to the highway are sinking. There are also many fallen limbs and leaves covering the ground.
notes: The Oak Grove Cemetery began as the the cemetery for the Oak City Baptist Church in 1873 and supported the freedmen's village of Method. There are approximately 403 individuals buried here and 113 gravemarkers are visible, the earliest going back to 1885. Many of the markers in the center, older section of the cemetery have been lost to time. The Method community was home to the Berry O'Kelly, one of its first settlers. Berry O'Kelly became a successful businessman, banker, and land owner. In 1914 he founded the Berry O'Kelly Training School, one of three schools for Black citizens in the state. O'Kelly is buried in front of what remains of that campus. The buildings are now part of the Method Comminity Park, maintained by the City of Raleigh. In 1965, construction of the I-440 Beltline cut the cemetery off from the Method community, even so, the cemetery continues to support the Method community today.
subject: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Oak Grove Cemetery; Freedman's village; African-American Cemetery
rightsstatement: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 Deed | Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 4.0 International | Creative Commons

notes: The Oak Grove Cemetery began as the the cemetery for the Oak City Baptist Church in 1873 and supported the freedmen's village of Method. There are approximately 403 individuals buried here and 113 gravemarkers are visible, the earliest going back to 1885. Many of the markers in the center, older section of the cemetery have been lost to time. The Method community was home to the Berry O'Kelly, one of its first settlers. Berry O'Kelly became a successful businessman, banker, and land owner. In 1914 he founded the Berry O'Kelly Training School, one of three schools for Black citizens in the state. O'Kelly is buried in front of what remains of that campus. The buildings are now part of the Method Comminity Park, maintained by the City of Raleigh. In 1965, construction of the I-440 Beltline cut the cemetery off from the Method community, even so, the cemetery continues to support the Method community today.

title: Grave markers of Chanie O' Kelly and Lafayette Ligon
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Two granite, engraved grave markers.
resident: O' Kelly, Chanie and Ligon, Lafayette
locationincemetery: Row 5. Straight back and to the left from the gravel road off of Ligon. The site is further back from the prominent Wilcox memorial.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Oak Grove Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: Both markers are replacements of the original markers and speak to the historical significance of both individuals. Both markers are in good condition and slightly stained by elemental exposure.
epitaph: CHANIE O' KELLY/ JULY 4, 1863/ JULY 7, 1902; LAFAYETTE LIGON/ FEB 14, 1826/ MAR 29, 1891
birthdate: Chanie O' Kelly- 1863/07/04 and Lafayette Ligon- 1826/02/14
dateofdeath: Chanie O' Kelly- 1902/07/07 and Lafayette Ligon- 1891/03/29
notes: Chanie O' Kelly is the first wife of Method founder Berry O' Kelly and the daughter of founder Lafayette Ligon whom she is buried next to. Chanie O' Kelly predeceased her husband by twenty-nine years and this is likely why she is buried next to her father. The couple had no children. Lafayette Ligon is one of the founders of the Method Community for whom Ligon Street is named and he helped to build the original Oak City Baptist Church in 1873. The original chuch occupied space in the southwest corner of the cemetery until 1878 when it moved to Method Road at Ligon Street where it sits today. The grave markers in this photo were put in place years after the deaths of Chanie O' Kelly and Lafayette Ligon and replace the original markers.
subject: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Oak Grove Cemetery; Freedman's village; African-American Cemetery; O' Kelly, Chanie; Ligon, Lafayette

title: Headstone of Octoria Wilder
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Larget concrete, engraved headstone.
locationincemetery: Row 5. Straight back and to the left from the gravel road off of Ligon. The site is to the left of the Chanie O'Kelly and Lafayette Ligon memorials.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Oak Grove Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: The headsone is in fairly good condition and stil readable. The year of death is listed as 1825 when it is in fact 1925. There is discoloration and erosion from elemental exposure.
epitaph: DAU/ OCTORIA/ WILDER/ JUL 25 1896/ MAY 2 1825/ AT REST
notes: Relative of Merritt and William Wilder who along with other founders of the Method community pooled their money to purchase fifty-five acres of land of the former Tucker and Company Lead Mine in the late 1870s. This allowed the Method community to grow as this land was subdivided and lots were sold to other Black families.

title: Headstone of Luke Hill
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Marble headstone engraved with a cross and crown. The symbol of the Oddfellows organization representing friendship, love, and truth is engraved above his name.
locationincemetery: Row 9. Straight back and to the left from the gravel road off of Ligon. The site is near the back of the cemetery.
location: Raleigh, North Carolina; Wake County; Oak Grove Cemetery
conditionofburialsite: The headstone is in good condition and still readable. There is some discoloration from elemental exposure.
epitaph: LUKE HILL/ BORN/ AUG. 5, 1849/ DIED/ APR. 19, 1914/ OUR LOVING FATHER/ DEVOTED HUSBAND/ GONE BUT NOT FORGOTTEN
notes: Luke Hill is listed as a laborer and was likely a member of the Oddfellows association given that its emblem is engraved on his headstone. His birthdate indicates he would have been among the founders of the Method community.

title: Long shot of the Purefoy cemetery (Black)
creator: Suess, Kim
description: A collection of headstones in a heavily wooded and overgrown lot.
resident: Descendants of the servants of the Purefoy family and possibly their ancestors.
locationincemetery: This cemetery is locted at the corner of Parkside Circle and Meeting Street in the Southern Village subdivision in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. There is no clear path into the cemetery and much of it is overgrown.
location: Chapel Hill, North Carolina; Orange County; Purefoy Cemetery (Black)
conditionofburialsite: The cemetery is hidden inside of a heavilly overgrown wooded lot at the corner of Meeting Street and Parkside Circle in the Southern Village subdivision. Of the three visible headstones only two are readable and one has had some kind of plaster smeared of the epitaph makingit unreadable. The funeral marker, once readable, is now unreadable. The fieldstone which once bore the initials FB is now clean.
notes: There are are four marked graves, one fieldstone, and a funeral marker visible. Additionally there are likely a number of other graves on the site marked by depressions and fieldstones. A cemetery survey done in 2011 by Ernest Dollar of the Chapel Hill Preservation Society indicates that the site holds many unanswered questions but is likely the resting place of the ancestors of those whose burial markers are visible. There is another cemetery in the Southern Village subdivision for the members of the white Purefoy family that once owned this land. The year 1904 was chosen for the timeline year as that is the oldest date on the headstones. It is likely that there are individuals buried in this cemetery that are much older than that.
subject: Chapel Hill, North Carolina; Orange County; Purefoy Cemetery (Black); African-American Cemetery
rightsstatement: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 Deed | Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 4.0 International | Creative Commons

title: Headstone of Lizzie Harris and funeral marker of Ruffian Booze
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Engraved granite headstone and footstone. There is a funeral marker in front of the headstone that is no longer readable.
locationincemetery: This cemetery is locted at the corner of Parkside Circle and Meeting Street in the Southern Village subdivision in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. There is no clear path into the cemetery and much of it is overgrown.
location: Chapel Hill, North Carolina; Orange County; Purefoy Cemetery (Black)
conditionofburialsite: The headstone looks to have been broken in half at some point and then reapired. It is discolored because of elemental exposure and still quite readable. The funeral home marker is intact but no longer readable. It is known what it said because of the survey done in 2011 by Ernest Dollar of the Chapel Hill Preservation Society.
epitaph: MOTHER/ LIZZIE/ HARRIS/ June 4 1863/ Dec. 25 1925/ Gone but not forgotten
notes: According to the cemetery census Lizzie Harris was the wife of Alex Harris and the daughter of Sam Purify (Purfoy) and Lucinda Merry (Merritt?). This information comes from a Durham County North Carolina death record from 1925, page 141. The funeral marker is that of Ruffian Booze, the unmarried son of Johnnie Booze and Emily Purefoy who would have lived form approximately 1903-1930 according to the Durham County North Carolina death record from 1930, page 68. This information was researched by Ernest Dollar in 2011.

title: Unknown fieldstone
creator: Suess, Kim
description: Large fieldstone that once bore the initials FB in green paint. The paint has now faded.
resident: Possibly a member of the Booze family
locationincemetery: This cemetery is locted at the corner of Parkside Circle and Meeting Street in the Southern Village subdivision in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. There is no clear path into the cemetery and much of it is overgrown.
location: Chapel Hill, North Carolina; Orange County; Purefoy Cemetery (Black)
conditionofburialsite: A large fieldstone that we know once bore the initials FB in green paint.
notes: This fieldstone possibly marks the grave of a member of the Booze family. Johnnie Booze married Emily Purefoy who is listed as being buried on this site, Durham County North Carolina Death Record 1928, page 40. Emily Purefoy was the daughter of Sam Purfoy and Sendy (Lucinda) Merrick (Merritt?) who are also listed as being buried in this cemetery according to Durham County North Carolina Death Records 1911 page 37 and 1918 page 185 respectively. All this information is known because of a cemetery survey and subsequent research done by Ernest Dollar of the Chapel Hill Preservation Society in 2011.
